The title If I Forget Thee, Jerusalem alludes to Psalms 137: “By the rivers of Babylon, there we sat down, yea, we wept, when we remembered Zion,” a passage concerning captivity and freedom that echoes throughout Faulkner’s novel.
The Wild Palms (New York: New American Library, 1948); The Old Man (New York: New American Library, 1948). In these volumes the definite article “The” was added to the title “Old Man.”
The Wild Palms and The Old Man (New York: New American Library, 1954).

Faulkner had little leverage with Random House in 1939. Absalom, Absalom! (1936) had not sold well, and the biblical title If I Forget Thee, Jerusalem was judged commercially risky, prompting the publisher’s change of title and its bowdlerizing of the text. After Faulkner won the Nobel Prize in 1949, such editorial interference ceased.
Both the manuscript and the setting-copy typescript have been reproduced in facsimile in William Faulkner Manuscripts, vol. 14, parts 1–2, ed. Thomas L. McHaney (New York & London: Garland, 1986).
Thomas L. McHaney, “William Faulkner’s The Wild Palms: A Textual and Critical Study” (PhD diss., University of South Carolina, 1968), esp. Appendix I, “The Text,” pp. 252–65.
The corrected text appears in William Faulkner, Novels 1936–1940 (New York: Library of America, 1990), 493–726.
